Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on social media posts and articles that question the presence of UN peacekeepers in Malawi.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by the spokesperson for UN Peacekeeping, who stated that the armoured carriers were heading from Malawi to the UN stabilisation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the UN has no mission or mandate in Malawi to conduct operations, as confirmed by the UN Peacekeeping spokesperson.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the situation by suggesting that the UN has sent peacekeepers to Malawi to bolster security, when in fact, the armoured carriers were being moved for rotation into the UN mission in the DRC.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as some posts and articles questioned why the armoured carriers were in Malawi or suggested they were on their way to the DRC, creating uncertainty about their purpose.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim may involve a problematic assumption that the presence of armoured carriers in Malawi indicates the deployment of peacekeepers by the United Nations, without considering alternative explanations.
